newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: HORSE RACING-TERRIFIC SCENES OF JOY AS DANOLI WINS HENNESSY.
newsitem.headline: HORSE RACING-TERRIFIC SCENES OF JOY AS DANOLI WINS HENNESSY.

text.p: Ireland's latest equine star Danoli captured the Hennessy Cognac Gold Cup at Leopardstown on Sunday and was immediately named a runner in the Cheltenham Gold Cup.

Danoli, a 6-1 chance, had fallen on two of his five previous outings over fences but jumped magnificently on this occasion under jockey Tommy Treacy to win the three-mile (4.8 kms) race by 1-1/2 lengths.
"Thank God that's over. We will now go for the Cheltenham Gold Cup," County Carlow-based trainer Tom Foley told the ecstatic record 20,000 crowd. That race is on March 13.

Jodami (5-1), winner of three successive Hennessy Gold Cups starting in 1993 and denied the chance to bid for a fourth by an 11th hour setback a year ago, finished strongly to come home second 20 lengths ahead of evens-favourite Imperial Call.

Imperial Call, winner of the 1996 Cheltenham Gold Cup, finished with a cut on one one hind leg but trainer Fergie Sutherland said his stable star was fine and would attempt to retain his title in March.
Sutherland said Imperial Call would have one more run before the Cheltenham Festival, in a steeplechase at Gowran Park on February 15.

Dublin bookmakers quoted Danoli an 8-1 chance for the Cheltenham race with Imperial Call second-favourite at 6-1. Another Irish-trained runner, Dorans Pride, has been installed as the pre-race favourite at 4-1.
Earlier, the Michael Hourigan-trained Dorans Pride, ridden by Shane Broderick, won the Grade Two Scalp Novice Steeplechase.
"If the ground is fast or firm at Cheltenham he will not run there," Tom Doran, his owner, said.

Dorans Pride (8-11 favourite) made all the running over the two miles and five furlongs (4.2 kms) trip and had six lengths to spare over Richard Dunwoody on second-placed See More Business, trained by Paul Nicholls in Britain.

Aidan O'Brien's Istabraq, with Ireland's champion jockey Charlie Swan riding, remained on course for one of the top hurdle races at Cheltenham with a head victory over stablemate Finnegan's Hollow in the Grade Two Deloitte and Touche Novice Hurdle over two miles and two furlongs (3.6 kms).
